On a bipartisan, unanimous vote this week, the California Senate Judiciary Committee  passed my SB 750. This bill is a first-of-its-kind housing finance solution  that could fast-track the construction of thousands of affordable homes needed throughout California without burdening taxpayers. With federal cuts to HUD and various housing programs, now more than ever, the state needs to use every tool it has to produce housing.   Senate Bill 750 now moves forward to the Senate Appropriations Committee.  This is not just another housing bill‚Äîit‚Äôs a structural reform to how we finance housing. SB 750 could be the key to unlocking hundreds of thousands of shovel-ready homes currently stuck in limbo.  The bill is called the California Housing Finance & Credit Act. It establishes a state-backed credit program administered by the California Housing Finance Agency.   The goal of the program is to keep housing projects moving forward instead of being bogged down for years with high interest rates.

Today marks the 50th anniversary of the fall of Saigon and South Vietnam that is known as Black April.   Events to commemorate this period in history are being held all over the state of California including a bus trip I co-sponsored from San Jose to Sacramento. Please take a minute to read the captions under the photos to see where some of these events took place.   As many as 250,000 South Vietnamese soldiers, hundreds of thousands of Vietnamese civilians and nearly 60,000 American soldiers died during the Vietnamese War.   Today for the first-time the Vietnamese Heritage and Freedom Flag was flown across the street from the Capitol in Sacramento. It was a powerful message to future generations that the thousands who sacrificed their lives so they could have the opportunity of freedom will never be forgotten.   The County of Santa Clara, California has one of the largest Vietnamese-American populations outside of Vietnam. I have been honored to represent the Vietnamese-American community as a school board member, a San Jose City Councilmember, a Santa Clara County Supervisor and now as a state Senator.   I authored the resolution allowing the South Vietnamese flag to fly legally anywhere in San Jose and Santa Clara County. The South Vietnamese flag is recognized by the city of San Jose, the County of Santa Clara and the state of California as the official heritage flag of Vietnamese Americans in California.

The @mothersmilkbankca today held a news conference in @countyofsantaclara to announce I am joining the organization in authoring SR 20 declaring May as California Human Milk Donation Month.  This is in honor of the dedicated efforts of human-milk donors, milk banks, health care providers, and advocates who work tirelessly to ensure that all infants have access to life-sustaining breast milk.  I will present SR 20 on the Senate floor next week.    Nonprofit milk banks serve these special needs, address disparities in access and education, and ensure there are safe processes for those donating and receiving donor breast milk. There are only two non-profit milk banks in California: Mothers‚Äô Milk Bank California in Santa Clara County and UC Health Milk Bank at UC San Diego. For information on how to get the milk or donate it go to: https://t.co/DR1pWjfuHF  Increased awareness of the importance of human milk donation can help all health systems better understand the communities that lack access and need improved access to these resources.

The death of Pope Francis will leave a huge void because of his lifelong commitment to the poor and marginalized.  He was a man of the people, even riding the subway as a Cardinal in Buenos Aires, and he never lost his great compassion and humanity as he rose through the ranks of the Catholic Church to become Pope.   He also never lost his  legendary sense of humor that belied his seriousness of purpose. And he never avoided asking the tough questions to world leaders.   He championed historically progressive stances  from immigrant rights to LGBTQ rights & climate change.  Pope Francis will be greatly missed.

Have you thought about purchasing your own electric bike but don‚Äôt have enough money saved up for one? Well, the State may be able to help.   On April 29th, applications for the E-Bike Incentive Program will open up once again aiming to reduce cost barriers to owning an electric bike for 1,000 low-income individuals. The program will grant vouchers worth up to $2,000 so that they may purchase an eligible, new electric bike.  As Chair of the Senate Transportation Committee, I am thrilled to see these types of programs support disadvantaged individuals who may not have transportation of their own while at the same time supporting our zero carbon emissions goals.   For additional details, and how to apply, visit the program‚Äôs website at: https://t.co/70NDjXclJL    #electricbike #environment #zerocarbonfootprint #zerocarbon #transportation @AirResources

Happiest of birthdays to the one and only Dolores Huerta ! My Senate colleagues and I had the privilege of declaring her birthdate, today, as Dolores Huerta Day across California.  Though she is more well-renowned for her tireless advocacy work with the United Farm Workers movement, she should also be known for her global imprint on the nonviolence movement. Her dialogue with former South African legislator, Ela Ghandi, who co-drafted South Africa's Constitution with Nelson Mandela post-apartheid is truly inspiring.   As a former farmer and farmworker, and nonviolence practitioner, I look forward to working side by side her in our collective fight to champion, defend, and work to protect the lives and rights of farmworkers across the state.  #UFW #DoloresHuerta #CesarEChavez #Farmworkers #ElaGhandi #NelsonMandela #SouthAfricanApartheid

At San Jose‚Äôs Mount Pleasant Elementary School, surrounded by education and community leaders, I unveiled Senate Bill 743 to reverse an antiquated 1978 funding formula that has created winners and losers in the public education system for the last 45 years.   This bill is about equalization and reversing the consequences of past mistakes. The bill would establish an education endowment using general fund money to equalize per pupil spending in districts throughout California. Districts that receive more property tax distributions give students more resources and educational opportunities than districts that receive less property tax distributions. Historically unfair property tax formulas determine per pupil spending!   Thank you to Dr. Lisa Andrew, President & CEO of the Silicon Valley Education Foundation; Dr. Elida MacArthur, superintendent of  #MountPleasantElementarySchoolDistrict; Glenn Vander Zee, superintendent of the  #EastsideUnionHighSchoolDistrict; Natalie Henriquez Mendoza, 8th grade student at August Boeger Middle School- San Jose & Lora Landeros, mother of three children who have all attended schools in East San Jose.  Click on this link in my bio to watch the news conference:   https://t.co/TnBEPhMWtl

I am deeply saddened to hear about the passing of my longtime, trusted friend and former colleague Don Gage.  To many Don was larger than life with a strong handshake, a hearty laugh and a ten  gallon personality that filled a room when he walked in.  I served with him on the VTA board and the Board of Supervisors and I saw a dedicated public servant able to cut to the chase to finish debates and make difficult negotiations.   It‚Äôs an art form for an elected official to not only have good, organized, clear thoughts but to be a leader who can use that clear thinking to conclude a debate.  Don was a registered Republican but he had a bipartisan streak making him objective, fair and effective.  I wish there were more people who could do that, especially with the polarization in Washington.  I will miss Don and am thinking of his wife and family.  For more on Don‚Äôs life, click on this Mercury News article.  https://t.co/Xbc0Ebw0DX

RT @StHelenaStar: Star editorial: Cabaldon for state Senate https://t.co/YJZOp3iTfn
Star editorial: Cabaldon for state Senate https://t.co/YJZOp3iTfn

"The person who clearly will represent the larger needs of the state and Napa County in this seat is Democrat Christopher Cabaldon, the two-decade-plus mayor of West Sacramento, who transformed an afterthought of a municipality into one of the state‚Äôs great turnaround cities. The board was impressed with the depth of his knowledge in education, land use and water issues. His plans to bolster wildfire mitigation as well as work to make community college free also resonated with us.  District 3 has no large municipalities within its boundaries, meaning the person in that seat must be an effective advocate for small and mid-size cities as well as rural areas. We felt Cabaldon understands this, particularly when it comes to housing equity and development issues.  Too much of the time, he told us in our interview, policies are focused on the state‚Äôs megalopolises, assuming that what works in Los Angeles will work in Calistoga; what makes sense for the Tenderloin also makes sense for American Canyon. Forcing cities, regardless of their size, to do things one way will only work for so long, he said. Collaboration is key. We agree and feel Cabaldon is best suited to put a nuanced plan into action." https://t.co/I6v8NHC22V via @NapaRegister

For the second time this year ‚Äì though now with proper public notice, after Assemblywoman Hadwick and I joined the ag community in calling for a new hearing in February‚Äì a committee of the state‚Äôs Fish and Game Commission on May 15th plans to discuss changing regulations on the take of coyotes. While this is an open discussion with no detailed plans, removing the ‚Äúnon-game mammal‚Äù status of coyotes could mean having to buy a tag, establishing seasons and setting bag limits, and having to seek a warden‚Äôs permission through a depredation permit to stop coyotes that are attacking livestock.    There is no scientific basis for establishing limits the way the Fish and Game Commission does for deer, ducks or other animals that we are trying to protect from over-hunting. These predators are more than abundant in rural areas and even in California‚Äôs suburban neighborhoods.    Recent years have seen a dramatic rise in the state protections for predators ‚Äì including bears and lions ‚Äì and new limits on the ability of everyone from full-time ranchers to families with backyard chickens to protect their animals. And that‚Äôs not even counting the spread of gray wolves, which enjoy the strictest legal protections even as they prey aggressively on cattle herds. Adding new protections for coyotes is the last thing rural communities need.    I am very grateful for the county sheriffs from around the North State who have joined in one voice to oppose any changes, which will not keep their communities safer.

RT @CAL_FIRE: The #ParkFire has now escalated to become the fifth-largest wildfire in California's history, severely impacting Butte, Tehama, Shasta, and Plumas counties. This development underscores the critical importance of being #ReadyforWildfire. One of the most effective ways to ensure safety is by signing up for emergency alerts, which provide timely information and instructions during wildfire events.  It's crucial to recognize that 95% of wildfires are caused by human activity. Therefore, taking proper precautions to prevent wildfires is everyone's responsibility. Simple actions such as following fire safety guidelines and avoiding activities that can spark fires are vital in reducing the risk. Additionally, having a go bag packed with essentials and being prepared for an emergency can make a significant difference in ensuring personal and community safety. For more information and tips on wildfire preparedness, visit https://t.co/pjQARzuq7u.  For updates on active statewide incidents, visit https://t.co/uTAuVrJXvU

Last week, Team Dahle had the honor of paying tribute to Fred Salanti at his funeral in Shasta County. Mr. Salanti, the visionary behind the Missing in America Project (MIAP), dedicated his life to locating, identifying, and providing dignified burials for the unclaimed remains of American veterans. Through MIAP, which relies primarily on private donations, over 2,000 veterans have been laid to rest across the nation. Having courageously served his country in Vietnam as a young man, Salanti's later years were marked by his unwavering commitment to his fellow veterans. He tirelessly supported services at the Redding CalVet home in Shasta County and took immense pride in ensuring that veterans, whose remains had been forgotten, received the proper military honors they deserved through MIAP, an organization he founded. His life exemplified heroism and service in its truest form. My heartfelt condolences go out to his family.

Six exceptional schools in our 1st Assembly District have been recognized among California's top elementary and secondary schools in the 2024 Distinguished Schools Program:  Jackson Junior High (Amador County Unified, Amador County) Diamond View Middle (Susanville Elementary, Lassen County) William & Marian Ghidotti High (Nevada Joint Union High, Nevada County) Central Valley High (Gateway Unified, Shasta County) Enterprise High (Shasta Union High District, Shasta County) University Preparatory School (Shasta Union High District, Shasta County)  These schools have been singled out for their exceptional commitment to student success, innovation, and community support. Their dedication to excellence is an example of the educational standards we uphold in our district. Their achievements underscore the importance of investing in education and providing our students with the resources they need to thrive.  As your representative, and the Vice Chair of the Assembly Education Committee for the second consecutive year, I have always prioritized our children's education, particularly in rural areas like ours. I firmly believe that every child, regardless of their ZIP code, deserves access to a high-quality education that prepares them for success in the modern world.  Congratulations to Jackson Junior High, Diamond View Middle, William & Marian Ghidotti, Central Valley High, Enterprise High, and University Preparatory School.

Here is a portion of today's hearing on utility rates when @SenAishaWahab (D-Hayward) spoke to the CA Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) president about how increased utility costs and the CPUC's decision to approve 6 PG&E rate hikes in the last year impacted everyday Californians.   "Those on a fixed income --  our senior population, those on social security, those with a union job, a good paying union job ‚Äî do not get six increases to their pay, and yet PG&E gets six increases to be able to toss onto ratepayers," she said, adding "ratepayers are not a bank."  I will have more with her tomorrow on @kron4news and other stations across the state about her new bill SB 332 -- The Investor-Owned Utility Accountability Act -- to limit rate increases from investor-owned utilities.

I thank Senator @ShannonGroveCA and every advocate and survivor who has come together to fight to #EndHumanTrafficking.

Today marks an incredible victory for California children. With the signing of my bill, SB 1414, we are reaffirming our commitment to safeguarding the most vulnerable among us‚Äîour children. SB 1414 (Grove) increases the penalty for soliciting or purchasing a child for sex from a misdemeanor to a felony, with a caveat that 16 and 17-year-olds must be proven victims of human trafficking. Criminals have been far ahead of us when it comes to child sex trafficking, we must have a strong approach to eradicate this brutal crime and ensure no child is reduced to a commodity.  The enactment of both of my bills, SB 14 last year and SB 1414 today, provides a significant step in the right direction to protect our children from both child sex traffickers and buyers. This is a crucial step, yet there is still work to be done. My pledge to champion protections for ALL children in California remains unwavering.

HINDU TEMPLE VANDALIZED IN HATE CRIME INCIDENT ¬† At approximately 9 AM on Wednesday, September 25, 2024, Officers from the Rancho Cordova Police Department and Deputies from the Sacramento County Sheriff‚Äôs responded to the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, a Hindu temple, to the report of graffiti and property damage.¬† Officers and Deputies arrived on scene and observed graffiti on the temple‚Äôs marquee signage and paved driveway on the temple property, with hateful messaging directed at Hindus.¬† They also discovered water pipes near the building had been intentionally cut and severely damaged. ¬† Based on their investigation, the incident was classified as a hate crime.¬† Detectives from the Sacramento County Sheriff‚Äôs Gang Suppression Unit, which investigates hate crimes in Sacramento County, responded to the scene and began their investigation.¬† Allied State and Federal law enforcement agencies were also notified of the incident and will assist with the investigation.¬† Detectives learned the vandalism was committed overnight, and a video of the incident was posted online on social media.¬† The investigation is in its early stages, and no suspect(s) have been identified. ¬† If you have information about this incident, please contact the Sheriff‚Äôs Office at (916) 874-5115 or Sacramento Valley Crime Stoppers at (916) 443-HELP (4357). Tips leading to an arrest are eligible for a cash reward of up to $1000, and tipsters remain anonymous.¬† Tips are paid in cash, and you are never asked for identification.¬† Contact Sacramento Valley Crime Stoppers at (916) 443-HELP (4357), 1-800-AA-CRIME, or **TIPS.¬† Use the ‚ÄúP3 TIPS‚Äù app or online at https://t.co/5EuuiLKxi3.¬† Tip information may also be left anonymously at https://t.co/JKzm2RNyXF or by calling (916) 874-TIPS (8477).

I am proud to author #SCR68, proclaiming this week as #TardiveDyskinesiaAwarenessWeek. RT @EytanWallace: NOW: Actor and activist @Janefonda is at the CA State Capitol to urge support for the ‚ÄúMake Polluters Pay‚Äù bills SB 684 & AB 1243 by @SenatorMenjivar (D-San Fernando Valley) and Asm. Dawn Addis (D-Morrow Bay).  ‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs not easy to go up against big oil, but we have to,‚Äù Fonda said.  Per the bill authors, the bill will do the following:  The bill identifies and assesses a fee on some fossil fuel companies based on their fossil fuel emissions since 1990.¬† The Polluters Pay Climate Superfund Act will: ‚Ä¢Direct CalEPA to complete a climate cost study¬†to¬†quantify total damages to the state (through 2045), caused by past fossil fuel emissions. ‚Ä¢Direct CalEPA to identify responsible parties and assess compensatory fees on the largest fossil fuel polluters proportional to their fossil fuel emissions 1990 through 2024, to address damages quantified in the cost study. ‚Ä¢Fund California‚Äôs future. Fees collected will fund projects and programs to mitigate disaster related rate increases for Californians and remedy or prevent climate-related costs and harms. The bill prioritizes labor and job standards and dedicates at least 40% of the funds to benefit disadvantaged communities.

Today, the California Armenian Legislative Caucus Foundation sent a letter condemning UC Berkeley's decision to cancel the screening of the film¬†My Sweet Land¬†scheduled for April 24 ‚Äî Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day.   "According to various reports, this decision followed pressure from the Consulate of Azerbaijan and several graduate students affiliated with an Azerbaijani state-sponsored scholarship program. After millions of views spreading lies about the Palisades firefighters lacking water because of regulations, the boring truth comes late like usual and wont be shared. Here it is:  1 - Reservoirs and water tanks were at normal levels and completely full before the fire.  2 - All 114 city water supply tanks were fully stocked pre-fire.  3 - A 15-hour surge at four times normal demand reduced water pressure.  4 - High demand at lower elevations slowed refilling tanks at higher elevations.  5 - This unprecedented fire was fueled by 8 months of no rain and 85 MPH winds. Water is being brought in continuously.  6 - Even if, like Trump claimed, the protection of the Delta Smelt caused over regulation by California, it's the FEDERAL Endangered Species Act that requires the protection of endangered species like the Delta Smelt and their habitats, not Gavin Newsom or California. Two of our bills passed Senate Judiciary Committee!   SB 414 expands oversight of charter schools to prevent fraud, improve governance and transparency, and hold bad actors accountable by implementing recommendations from a number of recent reports.  SB 720 is a pedestrian safety measure that allows cities to opt in to utilize an automated traffic enforcement system for safety violations occurring at red lights. Thank you to @TheCityofSac @SacPolice @SacPoliceChief for providing lead support testimony on this bill today.  Happy to be working on both of these important issues with great partners in my local community, including the much appreciated bipartisan support of @saccounty‚Äôs other  Senator, @SenRogerNiello

üåü So proud to honor Tina Kennedy as District 33's Woman of the Year! Tina began her teaching journey in 1981 in Long Beach, CA, at just 18 years old. She later moved to Avalon in Catalina Island, where she dedicated 40 years to shaping young minds first as a teacher, and then as Director at P.L.A.Y. Preschool. Through nature-based learning, arts and crafts, and strong family engagement, she nurtured confidence, curiosity, and a love for education in countless children and parents. After an incredible career, she retired last year, leaving a lasting legacy in the community she served so passionately.   Let's keep celebrating the incredible women in our communities this month and every day! #WomensHistoryMonth #womanoftheyear

So, is an unsigned bill leading to warehouse vacancies that will not be impacted by AB 98? Seems like a big leap.   What isn‚Äôt a big leap is if you ask Californians if they want a warehouse and idling trucks 500 ft from their home, they‚Äôd say no.   That‚Äôs what AB 98 addresses.

AB 98 is a clear signal to an industry that makes up 14% of the state GDP and supports 1:51 jobs nationally that they are not welcome here. To say that stopping NEW development doesn't affect existing warehouses and companies' decisions is simply false. Look at our housing crisis. CA policies have basically frozen new construction. RT @SenatorAshby: With a somber heart I joined @CASenateDems in Palisades, Santa Monica, Pasadena and Altadena for conversations and a tour led by some incredibly resilient local community leaders - including several California State Senators.  The first photo is of an Altadena middle school, with the charred remnants of a brand new student led vegetable garden right in the middle of a neighborhood designated as a food desert. Once a point of tremendous pride - now a stark reminder of the toll these devastating fires have taken on everyone - especially the littlest Californians.   There is much work to do.   I‚Äôm proud to author a bill that is part of the Senate Fire Response package.   The bill seeks to:  - keep licensed impacted businesses open during the recovery. - address predatory real estate practices. - enforce against fraudulent contractors. - provide small business relief from state requirements. - implement lessons learned from previous emergency situations to improve communication between licensed businesses and oversight agencies.   - streamline portions of rebuild processes for cost and time efficiencies.  *photos are all from Altadena.
